title: Disney Plus added 8m subscribers over Christmas
text:
Disney said the pandemic knocked $2.6bn from its operating income in the most recent quarter, as its once-mighty theme parks were shuttered or operating at limited capacity. 

And the world's largest entertainment company warned the pandemic would increase its costs by about $1bn in the current fiscal year, because it has to spend more on safety measures to combat the spread of the virus. 

It revealed, however, that it had lured nearly 95m subscribers to its flagship Disney Plus streaming service, the big bet that has cemented the legacy media group as a serious rival to Netflix. Disney shares climbed more than 3 per cent in after-hours trade.

The stock has jumped by more than a third in the past year as investors focused on the promise of streaming instead of the billions of dollars lost to the pandemic. 

Subscribers to Disney Plus grew from 87m on December 2 to 95m a month later, the company said, helped by the Christmas Day premiere of Soul, a critically acclaimed Pixar film.

Streaming is a costly business, as entertainment companies lavish funding on fresh shows and films to lure subscribers. Disney plans to double its annual content investment to about $15bn by 2024, at which point its streaming business would turn a profit, the company has predicted.

Its direct to consumer business unit — which includes Disney Plus, Hulu and ESPN — posted an operating loss of $466m on $3.5bn in sales during the quarter ending on January 2. 

Overall, Disney's operating income shrunk 67 per cent to $1.3bn in the quarter and would have been $2.6bn higher without the effects of the pandemic, it said. Net income of $29m compared with $2.1bn in the same quarter the year before, on total revenues that were down 22 per cent to $16.2bn.

On an adjusted basis, Disney posted earnings of 32 cents a share, down nearly 80 per cent from a year ago, but eclipsing Wall Street forecasts.
